elements.content: Co2{[N(CN)2]4bpym}·H2O (1) and M{[N(CN)2]2bpym}·H2O [M = Mn (2a), Fe (2b), Co (2c); bpym = 2,2‘-bipyrimidine] have been synthesized and characterized structurally and magnetically. All of the compounds crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Pnma. The unit cell parameters for 1 are a = 16.1684(5) Å, b = 12.9860(3) Å, c = 10.4207(3) Å, and Z = 4. Compound 1 is a 2-D layered structure with water intercalated between sheets. The sheets are composed of ···M−[NCNCN]2−M−bpym−M−[NCNCN]2−M··· chains, which are linked together by dicyanamides. 2a−c are isomorphic with the unit cell parameters a = 17.5112(4) Å, b = 11.9955(4) Å, c = 7.4684(2) Å for 2a, a = 17.5814(7) Å, b = 11.9453(5) Å, c = 7.3292(3) Å for 2b, a = 17.8642(2) Å, b = 11.9216(2) Å, c = 7.2860(2) Å for 2c, and Z = 4 for all. They crystallize as chains containing metal centers coordinated to two bridging dicyanamides, one terminal dicyanamide, one terminal chelating bpym, and one water molecule. 2a−c are the first examples of compounds containing terminal and μ-bound dicyanamides in the same structure. The broad maximum in the magnetic susceptibility of 1 could not be fit to any known dimer models. However, the high-temperature data were fit to the Curie−Weiss expression with g = 2.86 and θ = −42 K. 2a−c could best be modeled as uniform 1-D chains with g = 2.04, θ = −0.76, and J/k B = −0.15 K for 2a, g = 2.34, θ = −7.6, and J/k B = −0.42 K for 2b, and g = 2.58, θ = −5.4, and J/k B = −1.42 K for 2c. Because of small exchange coupling throughout the extended networks, no long-range magnetic ordering was observed.
elements.clean_text: Co2{[N(CN)2]4bpym}⋅H2O (1) and M{[N(CN)2]2bpym}⋅H2O [M = Mn (2a), Fe (2b), Co (2c); bpym = 2,2‘-bipyrimidine] have been synthesized and characterized structurally and magnetically. All of the compounds crystallize in the orthorhombic space group Pnma. The unit cell parameters for 1 are a = 16.1684(5) Å, b = 12.9860(3) Å, c = 10.4207(3) Å, and Z = 4. Compound 1 is a 2-D layered structure with water intercalated between sheets. The sheets are composed of ⋅⋅⋅M-[NCNCN]2-M-bpym-M-[NCNCN]2-M⋅⋅⋅ chains, which are linked together by dicyanamides. 2a-c are isomorphic with the unit cell parameters a = 17.5112(4) Å, b = 11.9955(4) Å, c = 7.4684(2) Å for 2a, a = 17.5814(7) Å, b = 11.9453(5) Å, c = 7.3292(3) Å for 2b, a = 17.8642(2) Å, b = 11.9216(2) Å, c = 7.2860(2) Å for 2c, and Z = 4 for all. They crystallize as chains containing metal centers coordinated to two bridging dicyanamides, one terminal dicyanamide, one terminal chelating bpym, and one water molecule. 2a-c are the first examples of compounds containing terminal and μ-bound dicyanamides in the same structure. The broad maximum in the magnetic susceptibility of 1 could not be fit to any known dimer models. However, the high-temperature data were fit to the Curie-Weiss expression with g = 2.86 and θ = -42 K. 2a-c could best be modeled as uniform 1-D chains with g = 2.04, θ = -0.76, and J/k B = -0.15 K for 2a, g = 2.34, θ = -7.6, and J/k B = -0.42 K for 2b, and g = 2.58, θ = -5.4, and J/k B = -1.42 K for 2c. Because of small exchange coupling throughout the extended networks, no long-range magnetic ordering was observed.

elements.content: The reaction between 2,2‘-bipyrimidine (bpym), dicyanamide, and M(II) leads to a dimerlike structure typified by Co2{[N(CN)2]4bpym}·H2O and a chain structure typified by Co{[N(CN)2]2bpym}·H2O. These structures and the magnetic properties are reported.
elements.clean_text: The reaction between 2,2‘-bipyrimidine (bpym), dicyanamide, and M(II) leads to a dimerlike structure typified by Co2{[N(CN)2]4bpym}⋅H2O and a chain structure typified by Co{[N(CN)2]2bpym}⋅H2O. These structures and the magnetic properties are reported.

elements.content: Coordination metal complexes with 2-D and 3-D network structures are currently under intense investigation in the context of molecular-based magnetism. In particular, coordination polymers containing ligands with nitrile moieties have dominated the literature. Since the use of tetracyanoethylene (TCNE) in the synthesis of the first molecular magnet with a magnetic ordering above room temperature, V(TCNE) x , there have been a multitude of polymers created with cyanide, TCNE, 7,7,8,8-tetracyano-p-quinodimethane (TCNQ), tricyanomethanide, and dicyanamide.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination metal complexes with 2-D and 3-D network structures are currently under intense investigation in the context of molecular-based magnetism. In particular, coordination polymers containing ligands with nitrile moieties have dominated the literature. Since the use of tetracyanoethylene (TCNE) in the synthesis of the first molecular magnet with a magnetic ordering above room temperature, V(TCNE) x , there have been a multitude of polymers created with cyanide, TCNE, 7,7,8,8-tetracyano-p-quinodimethane (TCNQ), tricyanomethanide, and dicyanamide.

elements.content: Dicyanamide, which can bind to one, two, three, or four7e metals, is a versatile building block for multidimensional frameworks. In the case of three-dimensional dicyanamide complexes of M[N(CN)2]2 (M = V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) composition, magnetic ordering has been documented at temperatures as high as 47 K (M = Cr). The introduction of ancillary π-conjugated ligands (e.g., pyridine and pyrazine) to these systems has created a wide range of molecular architectures and a greater understanding of the correlation between structure and magnetic behavior.
elements.clean_text: Dicyanamide, which can bind to one, two, three, or four7e metals, is a versatile building block for multidimensional frameworks. In the case of three-dimensional dicyanamide complexes of M[N(CN)2]2 (M = V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) composition, magnetic ordering has been documented at temperatures as high as 47 K (M = Cr). The introduction of ancillary π-conjugated ligands (e.g., pyridine and pyrazine) to these systems has created a wide range of molecular architectures and a greater understanding of the correlation between structure and magnetic behavior.

elements.content: The bipyrimidine (bpym) ligand is known to facilitate strong antiferromagnetic coupling when coordinating in the bisbidentate mode (I) to metals lying in the plane defined by the bpym nitrogens. The two parallel three-atom superexchange pathways provided by bpym are superior to the five-atom pathway of the μ-dicyanamide ligand, and consequently, the magnetic susceptibility of such heteroleptic compounds exhibits a dimerlike broad maximum.
elements.clean_text: The bipyrimidine (bpym) ligand is known to facilitate strong antiferromagnetic coupling when coordinating in the bisbidentate mode (I) to metals lying in the plane defined by the bpym  nitrogens. The two parallel three-atom superexchange pathways provided by bpym are superior to the five-atom pathway of the μ-dicyanamide ligand, and consequently, the magnetic susceptibility of such heteroleptic compounds exhibits a dimerlike broad maximum.

elements.content:
<fig id="ic991244rf1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label></label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic991244rf1.eps"></graphic>
</fig>

Herein, we present the structural characterization and magnetic properties of several first-row transition metal complexes containing both dicyanamide and bpym ligands. To our knowledge, M{[N(CN)2]2bpym}·H2O (M = Mn, Fe, Co) represents the first class of compounds containing multiple dicyanamide coordination modes in the same structure.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we present the structural characterization and magnetic properties of several first-row transition metal complexes containing both dicyanamide and bpym ligands. To our knowledge, M{[N(CN)2]2bpym}⋅H2O (M = Mn, Fe, Co) represents the first class of compounds containing multiple dicyanamide coordination modes in the same structure.

elements.content:
Materials. 2,2‘-Bipyrimidine (Lancaster), MnCl2·4H2O (J. T. Baker), CoSO4·7H2O (Fisher Scientific), Fe(BF4)2·6H2O, and NaN(CN)2 (Aldrich) were used as received.

Synthesis. (a) Co x {[N(CN) 2 ] 2 x bpym}·H 2 O ( x = 1, 2) (1 and 2c). A concentrated aqueous solution of CoSO4·7H2O (208.3 mg, 0.7409 mmol) was slowly added to a concentrated aqueous solution of bpym (58.5 mg, 0.3705 mmol) and NaN(CN)2 (131.9 mg, 1.482 mmol) with continuous stirring. After 3 days of slow evaporation, red crystals with two distinct morphologies were obtained. Small conglomerations of prismatic crystals (1) were present with plates (2c) in a ∼95:5 ratio. The crystals were filtered, washed with water, air-dried, and separated manually under a microscope. (Found for Co2{[N(CN)2]4bpym}·H2O [CoC8N8H4O0.5] (1):  C, 34.59; H, 1.46; N, 39.60. Anal. Calcd for 1:  C, 34.42; H, 1.43; N, 40.15. Found for Co{[N(CN)2]2bpym}·H2O [CoC12N10H8O] (2c):  C, 39.04; H, 2.17; N, 37.70. Anal. Calcd for 2c:  C, 39.24; H, 2.18; N, 38.15%).

Experimental Section12 

 Materials. 2,2‘-Bipyrimidine (Lancaster), MnCl2⋅4H2O (J. T. Baker), CoSO4⋅7H2O (Fisher Scientific), Fe(BF4)2⋅6H2O, and NaN(CN)2 (Aldrich) were used as received. 

 Synthesis. (a) Co   x   {[N(CN)  2  ]  2    x   bpym}⋅H  2  O (  x   = 1, 2) (1 and 2c). A concentrated aqueous solution of CoSO4⋅7H2O (208.3 mg, 0.7409 mmol) was slowly added to a concentrated aqueous solution of bpym (58.5 mg, 0.3705 mmol) and NaN(CN)2 (131.9 mg, 1.482 mmol) with continuous stirring. After 3 days of slow evaporation, red crystals with two distinct morphologies were obtained. Small conglomerations of prismatic crystals (1) were present with plates (2c) in a ~95:5 ratio. The crystals were filtered, washed with water, air-dried, and separated manually under a microscope. (Found for Co2{[N(CN)2]4bpym}⋅H2O [CoC8N8H4O0.5] (1): C, 34.59; H, 1.46; N, 39.60. Anal. Calcd for 1: C, 34.42; H, 1.43; N, 40.15. Found for Co{[N(CN)2]2bpym}⋅H2O [CoC12N10H8O] (2c): C, 39.04; H, 2.17; N, 37.70. Anal. Calcd for 2c: C, 39.24; H, 2.18; N, 38.15%).

elements.content: (b) Mn{[N(CN) 2 ] 2 bpym}·H 2 O (2a). 2a was prepared as described above from MnCl2·4H2O (134.6 mg, 0.7521 mmol). Crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained over a period of 3 days. The crystals were harvested, washed with water, and air-dried. (Found for MnC12N10H8O:  C, 39.80; H, 2.23; N, 38.43. Anal. Calcd:  C, 39.68; H, 2.20; N, 38.57%).

elements.content: (c) Fe{[N(CN) 2 ] 2 bpym}·H 2 O (2b). 2b was prepared as described above using Fe(BF4)2·6H2O (253.0 mg, 0.7495 mmol) in a Vacuum Atmospheres, Inc. DriLab. After 1 day, crystalline material suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction formed. The crystals were filtered, washed with water, and dried under an inert atmosphere. (Found for FeC12N10H8O:  C, 38.92; H, 2.04; N, 38.29. Anal. Calcd:  C, 39.58; H, 2.20; N, 38.48%).

elements.content: Physical Techniques. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Bio-Rad FTS-40 FTIR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4000−400 cm-1 region. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on powdered samples in either gelatin capsules or airtight holders in the temperature range 2−300 K using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL SQUID ac/dc magnetometer. Samples were cooled in zero field, and data were collected in a 1000 G field upon warming. Diamagnetic corrections for 1 (−169 × 10-6 emu mol-1) and 2a−c (∼ −265 × 10-6 emu mol-1) were calculated from Pascal's constants.
elements.clean_text: Physical Techniques. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Bio-Rad FTS-40 FTIR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on powdered samples in either gelatin capsules or airtight holders in the temperature range 2-300 K using a Quantum Design MPMS-5XL SQUID ac/dc magnetometer. Samples were cooled in zero field, and data were collected in a 1000 G field upon warming. Diamagnetic corrections for 1 (-169 × 10-6 emu mol-1) and 2a-c (~-265 × 10-6 emu mol-1) were calculated from Pascal's constants.

elements.content: X-ray Data Collection and Structure Refinement. Crystal data collection and refinement parameters are given in Table . Suitable crystals for data collection were selected and mounted with epoxy cement on the tip of a fine glass fiber. All data were collected with a Siemens P4 diffractometer equipped with a SMART/CCD detector.

Summary of Magnetic Data

μRT, μB θ, K g J/k B, K Co2{[N(CN)2]4bpym}·H2O (1) 5.16 −42 2.86 Mn{[N(CN)2]2bpym}·H2O (2a) 6.01 −0.76 2.04 −0.15 Fe{[N(CN)2]2bpym}·H2O (2b) 5.73 −7.6 2.34 −0.42 Co{[N(CN)2]2bpym}·H2O (2c) 4.96 −5.4 2.58 −1.42

The systematic absences in the diffraction data of all structures are consistent with the orthorhombic space group options Pna21 and Pnma. E statistics suggested the centrosymmetric space group, which yielded chemically reasonable and computationally stable results of refinement. Structures 1 and 2a were solved by direct methods, and compounds 2b,c were initiated from analogue coordinates. All were completed by subsequent difference Fourier syntheses and refined by full-matrix least-squares procedures. The isomorphous structures, 2a−c, possess crystallographically imposed, mirror plane disorder of the central nitrogen atom in all dicyanamide moieties. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement coefficients, and the hydrogen atoms were treated as idealized contributions. The protons could not be located on either the free water molecule of 1 or the coordinated water molecules of 2a−c and were omitted from the refinement.

All were completed by subsequent difference Fourier syntheses and refined by full-matrix least-squares procedures. The isomorphous structures, 2a-c, possess crystallographically imposed, mirror plane disorder of the central nitrogen atom in all dicyanamide moieties. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement coefficients, and the hydrogen atoms were treated as idealized contributions. The protons could not be located on either the free water molecule of 1 or the coordinated water molecules of 2a-c and were omitted from the refinement.

elements.content: Infrared Spectra. All compounds displayed strong absorptions in the 2315−2160 cm-1 region corresponding to νC ≡ N of the dicyanamide ligand. A sharp band at 3087 cm-1 apparent in 1 is assigned to hydrogen-bonding interactions, while broad absorptions around 3300 cm-1 (νs and νas, OH) were observed for 2a−c. The scissoring motion of unbound water in 1 was observed at 1627 cm-1, while that for bound water was observed near 1590 cm-1 in 2a−c (Figure ). The quasi-symmetric doublet characteristic of chelating bpym appears at 1573 and 1555 cm-1 in 2a−c. A smaller peak at 1565 cm-1 is also present in these compounds and may be indicative of bis-chelating impurities. 1 shows a strong broad absorption around 1580 cm-1 with a shoulder at lower wavenumbers. This pattern has been described as an asymmetric doublet characteristic of ring stretching for bis-chelating bpym.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Infrared Spectra. All compounds displayed strong absorptions in the 2315-2160 cm-1 region corresponding to νC ≡ N of the dicyanamide ligand. A sharp band at 3087 cm-1 apparent in 1 is assigned to hydrogen-bonding interactions, while broad absorptions around 3300 cm-1 (νs and νas, OH) were observed for 2a-c. The scissoring motion of unbound water in 1 was observed at 1627 cm-1, while that for bound water was observed near 1590 cm-1 in 2a-c (Figure ). The quasi-symmetric doublet characteristic of chelating bpym appears at 1573 and 1555 cm-1 in 2a-c. A smaller peak at 1565 cm-1 is also present in these compounds and may be indicative of bis-chelating impurities. 1 shows a strong broad absorption around 1580 cm-1 with a shoulder at lower wavenumbers. This pattern has been described as an asymmetric doublet characteristic of ring stretching for bis-chelating bpym.

elements.content: Description of the Structures. Co 2 {[N(CN) 2 ] 4 bpym}·H 2 O (1). 1 is composed of ···[NCNCN]2−M−bpym−M−[NCNCN]2··· sheets parallel to the b axis. These sheets are linked via μ-dicyanamide ligands, which propagate along the a axis (Figure ) with adjacent sheets offset by 38.2°. Each CoII is octahedral (Figure ) with Co···N bonds ranging from 2.075 to 2.167 Å. The Co···Co separation along b is 7.220 Å through the μ-dicyanamides and 5.766 Å via the bpym. The μ-dicyanamides coordinating along a produce Co···Co separations of 8.288 Å. The N(1)−Co−N(2) bpym bite angle is 76.97(11)°, which leads to the other equatorial angles being slightly larger than 90°. The deviation of the N(7)−Co−N(8) angle from linearity [168.70(13)°] is the result of H-bonding between waters of hydration found between the sheets, which stack along the c axis (Figure ), and amine N's of dicyanamides running along the a axis (N···O = 3.050 Å, N···O···N = 91.8°).
elements.clean_text: Description of the Structures. Co  2  {[N(CN)  2  ]  4  bpym}⋅H  2  O (1). 1 is composed of ⋅⋅⋅[NCNCN]2-M-bpym-M-[NCNCN]2⋅⋅⋅ sheets parallel to the b axis. These sheets are linked  via μ-dicyanamide ligands, which propagate along the a axis (Figure ) with adjacent sheets offset by 38.2°. Each CoII is octahedral (Figure ) with Co⋅⋅⋅N bonds ranging from 2.075 to 2.167 Å. The Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation along b is 7.220 Å through the μ-dicyanamides and 5.766 Å via the bpym. The μ-dicyanamides coordinating along a produce Co⋅⋅⋅Co separations of 8.288 Å. The N(1)-Co-N(2) bpym bite angle is 76.97(11)°, which leads to the other equatorial angles being slightly larger than 90°. The deviation of the N(7)-Co-N(8) angle from linearity [168.70(13)°] is the result of H-bonding between waters of hydration found between the sheets, which stack along the c axis (Figure ), and amine N's of dicyanamides running along the a axis (N⋅⋅⋅O = 3.050 Å, N⋅⋅⋅O⋅⋅⋅N = 91.8°).

elements.content: M{[N(CN) 2 ] 2 bpym}·H 2 O (2). Single-crystal X-ray structures for compounds of this stoichiometry were determined for M = Mn, Fe, Co. These structures are isomorphic and consist of interdigitated 1-D zigzag chains (Figures and ). These chains are formed by μ-[N(CN)2]2 --bridged metal centers. One nitrile-bound terminal dicyanamide, one bidentate bipyrimidine (II), and one water molecule occupy the remaining four metal coordination sites (Figure ). The terminal dicyanamide is rotationally disordered so that the thermal ellipsoids of the carbons could not be sufficiently separated. Therefore, a reliable determination of the N−C−N angles cannot be made. The nearest intrachain M···M distances are 8.983 Å (Mn), 8.630 Å (Fe), and 8.649 Å (Co). Because of the interdigitation of the chains, the nearest interchain M···M distances, 6.723 Å (Mn), 6.722 Å (Fe), and 6.735 Å (Co), are closer than the intrachain distances. As expected, the bpym bite angles, 71.64(17)° (Mn), 74.97(15)° (Fe), and 76.37(17)° (Co), are inversely related to the ionic radii of the metal centers.
elements.clean_text: M{[N(CN)  2  ]  2  bpym}⋅H  2  O (2). Single-crystal X-ray structures for compounds of this stoichiometry were determined for M = Mn, Fe, Co. These structures are isomorphic and consist of interdigitated 1-D zigzag chains (Figures  and ). These chains are formed by μ-[N(CN)2]2 --bridged metal centers. One nitrile-bound terminal dicyanamide, one bidentate bipyrimidine (II), and one water molecule occupy the remaining four metal coordination sites (Figure ). The terminal dicyanamide is rotationally disordered so that the thermal ellipsoids of the carbons could not be sufficiently separated. Therefore, a reliable determination of the N-C-N angles cannot be made. The nearest intrachain M⋅⋅⋅M distances are 8.983 Å (Mn), 8.630 Å (Fe), and 8.649 Å (Co). Because of the interdigitation of the chains, the nearest interchain M⋅⋅⋅M distances, 6.723 Å (Mn), 6.722 Å (Fe), and 6.735 Å (Co), are closer than the intrachain distances. As expected, the bpym bite angles, 71.64(17)° (Mn), 74.97(15)° (Fe), and 76.37(17)° (Co), are inversely related to the ionic radii of the metal centers.

elements.content: Two chains (bottom left and top right) of2. Interdigitation is shown in the central region. Disorder of dicyanamides has been removed for clarity.

elements.content: Magnetic Properties. The molar magnetic susceptibility, χ, of 1 and 2 were determined between 2 and 300 K (Figures and ). For 1, χ(T) increases with decreasing temperature until a maximum at ∼14 K is reached. The broad maximum in χ(T) implies antiferromagnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers. The antiferromagnetic coupling was confirmed by fitting the high-temperature 1/χ(T) data to the Curie−Weiss expression, χ ∝ (T − θ)-1, with θ = −42 K and g = 2.86. The χT(T) data decreases steadily upon cooling from 300 down to 2 K. The value of χT at room temperature is 3.33 emu K mol-1 (μeff = 5.16 μB), which is larger than the 1.875 emu K mol-1 (3.87 μB) expected for isolated S = 3/2 ions. This larger value is the result of contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperatures, which produces effective moments in the range 4.7−5.2 μB.
elements.clean_text: Magnetic Properties. The molar magnetic susceptibility, χ, of 1 and 2 were determined between 2 and 300 K (Figures  and ). For 1, χ(T) increases with decreasing temperature until a maximum at ~14 K is reached. The broad maximum in χ(T) implies antiferromagnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers. The antiferromagnetic coupling was confirmed by fitting the high-temperature 1/χ(T) data to the Curie-Weiss expression, χ ∝ (T - θ)-1, with θ = -42 K and g = 2.86. The χT(T) data decreases steadily upon cooling from 300 down to 2 K. The value of χT at room temperature is 3.33 emu K mol-1 (μeff =  5.16 μB), which is larger than the 1.875 emu K mol-1 (3.87 μB) expected for isolated S = 3/2 ions. This larger value is the result of contributions to the susceptibility from orbital angular momentum at high temperatures, which produces effective moments in the range 4.7-5.2 μB.

elements.content: Numerous attempts were made to model the data for 1 with varying degrees of success. Since it is known that the bpym bridge (−J/k B = 0.9−14 K) is a much better mediator of exchange than μ-dicyanamide (−J/k B ≈ 0.10−0.18 K), we fit the data to a singlet-septet (S tot = 3/2 ± 3/2) dimer model, where C = Ng 2μB 2/(k B T), N = Avogadro's number, g = Landé value, μB = Bohr magneton, k B = Boltzmann's constant, x = J/(k B T), and J = exchange coupling constant. This model, however, does not account for spin−orbit coupling and assumes that the dimerlike moieties are magnetically isolated, which they are not. Attempts to utilize a molecular field correction term to quantify the strength of residual interactions through the dicyanamide ligands did not improve the fit. Additionally, we tried the model that accounts for spin−orbit coupling and ligand field distortions developed by Figgis for 4T1g ions. This model was poor because it is meant for isolated monomers and does not include an exchange coupling parameter. Hence, without specific magnetic models describing heteroleptic planar structures we and others have been unable to provide detailed analyses of such compounds.
elements.clean_text: Numerous attempts were made to model the data for 1 with varying degrees of success. Since it is known that the bpym bridge (-J/k B = 0.9-14 K) is a much better mediator of exchange than μ-dicyanamide (-J/k B ~ 0.10-0.18 K), we fit the data to a singlet-septet (S tot = 3/2 ± 3/2) dimer model,     where C = Ng 2μB 2/(k B T), N = Avogadro's number, g = Landé value, μB = Bohr magneton, k B = Boltzmann's constant, x = J/(k B T), and J = exchange coupling constant. This model, however, does not account for spin-orbit coupling and assumes that the dimerlike moieties are magnetically isolated, which they are not. Attempts to utilize a molecular field correction term to quantify the strength of residual interactions through the dicyanamide ligands did not improve the fit. Additionally, we tried the model that accounts for spin-orbit coupling and ligand field distortions developed by Figgis for 4T1g ions. This model was poor because it is meant for isolated monomers and does not include an exchange coupling parameter. Hence, without specific magnetic models describing heteroleptic planar structures we and others have been unable to provide detailed analyses of such compounds.

elements.content: 2a−c have room temperature χT values of 4.52 (6.01) (M = Mn), 4.11 (5.73) (M = Fe), and 3.07 emu K mol-1 (4.96 μB) (M = Co). The close approximation between the experimental moment of 2a and the theoretical spin-only value for S = 5/2 (μeff = 5.92 μB) suggests that this compound contains largely isolated spins. However, as is typically observed for FeII and CoII, the room-temperature moments of 2b and 2c exceed the spin-only expectation values because of the contribution of orbital angular momentum. For example, the room-temperature moment of 2b (5.73 μB) is significantly larger than the expected spin-only value (4.90 μB) for S = 2 but is in good agreement with the moment reported (5.68 μB) for the related compound [Fe3(C2O4)3(4,4‘-bpy)4]. Above 150 K, the data can be fit to the Curie−Weiss expression giving θ = −0.76 (2a), −7.6 (2b),and −5.4 K (2c), indicating very weak antiferromagnetic coupling.
elements.clean_text: 2a-c have room temperature χT values of 4.52 (6.01) (M = Mn), 4.11 (5.73) (M = Fe), and 3.07 emu K mol-1 (4.96 μB) (M = Co). The close approximation between the experimental moment of 2a and the theoretical spin-only value for S = 5/2 (μeff = 5.92 μB) suggests that this compound contains largely isolated spins. However, as is typically observed for FeII and CoII, the room-temperature moments of 2b and 2c exceed the spin-only expectation values because of the contribution of orbital angular momentum. For example, the room-temperature moment of 2b (5.73 μB) is significantly larger than the expected spin-only value (4.90 μB) for S = 2 but is in good agreement with the moment reported (5.68 μB) for the related compound [Fe3(C2O4)3(4,4‘-bpy)4]. Above 150 K, the data can be fit to the Curie-Weiss expression giving θ = -0.76 (2a), -7.6 (2b),and -5.4 K (2c), indicating very weak antiferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: Because of the 1-D structure for 2, the magnetic data were fit to a Fisher chain model, which is valid for large values of S (Figure ), with g = 2.04 and J/k B = −0.15 K for 2a, g = 2.34 and J/k B = −0.42 K for 2b, and g = 2.58 and J/k B = −1.42 K for 2c. The small values of J/k B are consistent with weak antiferromagnetic coupling between paramagnetic spin sites. These data, together with the results from the previously reported Mn[N(CN)2]2L x (L = pyridine, 2,2‘-bipyridine) compounds, suggest that μ-[N(CN)2]2 - coordination provides only weak superexchange interactions as a result of negligible conjugation through the amine nitrogen.
elements.clean_text: Because of the 1-D structure for 2, the magnetic data were fit to a Fisher chain model, which is valid for large values of S (Figure ),    with g = 2.04 and J/k B = -0.15 K for 2a, g = 2.34 and J/k B = -0.42 K for 2b, and g = 2.58 and J/k B = -1.42 K for 2c. The small values of J/k B are consistent with weak antiferromagnetic coupling between paramagnetic spin sites. These data, together with the results from the previously reported Mn[N(CN)2]2L x  (L = pyridine, 2,2‘-bipyridine) compounds, suggest that μ-[N(CN)2]2 - coordination provides only weak superexchange interactions as a result of negligible conjugation through the amine nitrogen.

elements.content: Several heteroleptic compounds were synthesized and characterized utilizing both 2,2‘-bipyrimidine and dicyanamide ligands. In addition to containing a unique structural feature, namely, multiple binding modes for dicyanamide, the compounds provided the opportunity to study the effect of bpym chelation on magnetic properties. The superexchange pathway through bpym led to dimerlike behavior in the magnetic susceptibility data of the bisbidentate system. However, in the chain structure, when the bpym superexchange pathway was inoperable, only minimal spin interactions were observed.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Several heteroleptic compounds were synthesized and characterized utilizing both 2,2‘-bipyrimidine and dicyanamide ligands. In addition to containing a unique structural feature, namely, multiple binding modes for dicyanamide, the compounds provided the opportunity to study the effect of bpym chelation on magnetic properties. The superexchange pathway through bpym led to dimerlike behavior in the magnetic susceptibility data of the bisbidentate system. However, in the chain structure, when the bpym superexchange pathway was inoperable, only minimal spin interactions were observed.

elements.content: Heteroleptic systems give the chemist the opportunity to use multiple building blocks in the design of new materials. The properties of these materials that arise from ligand diversity are an important area of materials science. However, much of the future magnetic research will depend on new heteroleptic-specific models that allow chemists to quantify the amount of metal−metal communication present in these systems.
elements.clean_text: Heteroleptic systems give the chemist the opportunity to use multiple building blocks in the design of new materials. The properties of these materials that arise from ligand diversity are an important area of materials science. However, much of the future magnetic research will depend on new heteroleptic-specific models that allow chemists to quantify the amount of metal-metal communication present in these systems.

cln_elements.content: (b) Mn{[N(CN) 2 ] 2 bpym}·H 2 O (2a). 2a was prepared as described above from MnCl2·4H2O (134.6 mg, 0.7521 mmol). Crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained over a period of 3 days. The crystals were harvested, washed with water, and air-dried. (Found for MnC12N10H8O:  C, 39.80; H, 2.23; N, 38.43. Anal. Calcd:  C, 39.68; H, 2.20; N, 38.57%).

Anal. Calcd: C, 39.68; H, 2.20; N, 38.57%).

metadata.title:
Synthesis, Structure, and Magnetic Properties of Co2{[N(CN)2]4bpym}·H2O and
M{[N(CN)2]2bpym}·H2O (M = Mn, Fe, Co; bpym = 2,2‘-Bipyrimidine)
